Apr 7

Drive safe — freelancer tips

As freelancers we have to manage client relationships by ourselves: negotiations, contracts and timelines. Basically you don’t only have to master your work, but also be a legal and negotiation savvy. Each project is unique and so are relationships with every client.

This post is about the worst case of things going wrong. After various conversation with freelancers a very alarming pattern revealed: companies symptomatically fail or delay payments to young freelancers, due to some unpredictable circumstances or even consciously. It mostly affects emerging professionals with little experience. There are a lot of reasons why it happens: deadlines are not met, core concept changes on the way, company cannot allocate promised resources and so on. But one of the primary causes is a poorly managed contracts and an assumption that young person won’t take legal actions. Of course the safest way is to always have a lawyer at your back, but it is an expensive service and doesn’t always seem necessary. Based on various experiences, here are some very general tips, which can help to avoid a lot of pitfalls on the way.

Starting with the obvious: Contract

C-o-n-t-r-a-c-t. Under no circumstances you should work without a contract. Surprisingly it’s one of these things which is easy to say but hard to achieve. The basic notion is: if client refuses to sign a contract, it has to alert you. All the deadlines and very detailed description of work have to be written down and approved. It’s better to make it modular and break the whole package into deliverables: list all web pages you have to design, list all chapters of market analysis you have to write with every delivery deadline. There are some online templates to shape a fair contract with a client, it’s better to be written in the local language and refer to local regulations. The most secure way is to hire an attorney for one time consultancy to create a template for your future contracts. Consult them on every details you are not sure about: for example, depending on a country, client has an [x] days to react to an invoice, where to file a complaint in case you are not paid and so on. Your protection and rights in such situations highly depends on a country of fiscal residence so dig into local rules and check on international legislation in case you have foreign clients.

Deadlines

A lot of freelancers are familiar with the following situation: some part of work depends on a client and there is a delay. Say, you are a web designer, and need visual materials for the website (images, videos etc). The client is late, but the deadline is due. It may result in rushing last minute to recover wasted time and not sleeping for a night or two. This case has to be reflected in the contract: deadlines of your work have to go alongside with deadlines of the client. Document should specify what happens if one of these milestones is not met, usually you claim no responsibility for such delays or even charge extra for a last-minute work. Always be open about these terms and inform client in a written form that it is impossible to meet a deadline without pending materials.

Delays

What happens if the modular project is going way slower than you expected and the client is postponing next steps. For example, you have an order of a five brochures and the initial timeline was two weeks, you have made three of them (more than 50%) but still waiting for a content to finish remaining ones. In the meantime the client has a major change in the company structure and a new marketing director wants to revise the discourse of communication. You already rejected another job offer to work on this project and now you are not sure when it will re-start. So you lost money at the first place, opportunity costs are high, and you are also bound by a compromise to finish work. Now, this is one of the toughest situations to manage. Most of freelancers I know faced it at least once. Very few clients will sign a contract with a penalty clause in your favor in such a case, especially if you are young freelancer. So if you cannot afford a consulting attorney there is not much left to do but practicing your intuition: get to know your client better, ask around about their past experiences and still try to add a penalty clause. Is it a starup or established company? Is the funding for this product secured or you will be paid once the project is fully funded? Try to find answers and decide how solid are the grounds.

Changes

We all want to fulfill expectations of our clients, but sometimes ideas drastically evolve in the process. The good practice is to specify how many iterations you are planning to make. Here is the least harmful example, you are developing a website, and a client wants to change the text of a static page — how many times are you ready to do that and at what costs? Can you do it on ongoing basis or prefer to have one big list of changes every week for implementation. I bet you prefer the second option. So it’s very important that your contract reflects these rules and significant extra work has to translate into monetary or at least time framing consequences. In the end of the day we always do some extra or unexpected work, and that’s alright, but if changing one text 7 times in 3 days is troubling for you, you can be open about it. The best is to agree upon per hour rate and include it as a cost of additional hours into the contract.

Face-to-face meeting vs. written word

Any verbal conversation with your client has to reflect on some form of a written word: digital or paper. The general recommendation is to send a follow-up email after every meeting, where you provide a summary of a conversation and the bullet list of everything what has been decided. For example, you postponed a deadline because of some changes, or is not ready to provide you with necessary materials: write it down and send it to them. You set up a two-weeks deadline, write a short heads up email in the end of the first week and let them know what exactly you’ve done and how is the progress. Don’t be afraid to seem too communicative. Apart from expressing your anticipation of the project, email correspondence might play a crucial role in [unfortunate, but probable] legal or informal settlement of arguments.

In advance payment

Never be shy to ask for 50% upfront payment. It doesn’t only assure you that a client has resources but is also a sign that they are serious about the project and ready to follow-up with deadlines. Another option is 40/30/30 split, which usually works better for projects with higher budget and workload. Not everyone will bother transferring 150 € every two weeks. Some freelancers even offer early payment discounts, so there is a lot of room for creative encouragement of payment.

Know your contacts

If you work with organization make sure you know what person or people are assigned to your case, what their responsibilities are and who is your main contact in the organization. Understand what kind of issues you can address to each team member and what are their role in the project. Does any deadline depend on a specific person in this organization? Get their contact details and be in touch.

Estimate your abilities and respect client’s expectations

If a client asks for a deadline and you know you won’t make it, just say it straight away. Here we came to so-called “expectation management”. It’s always tempting to jump in adventure, especially when you like a client and a project. But do not promise or worse, sign on anything you know is very challenging. If for some reason you can’t deliver what you have promised, make you sure you notify your client in advance. No one likes last minute upsetting news so the earlier they know you are facing difficulties the better.

Hopefully these tips were helpful in some way.
